Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 07:08AM - edited Dec 8, 2009 07:09AM by KEW Hi-- Try not to focus on the size of the nodule.  Smaller is not always better and bigger is not always worse.  It depends on the biological characteristics of the tumor, if that is what it turns out to be.  A tiny tumor can be very aggressive, and a big tumor can be sleepy.  I know it seems nearly impossible, but try and stay in the moment and not project too far into the future, and stay away from the "what if" thinking that can really raise anxiety levels.  Regarding size, it often changes if surgery is required.  It can be smaller or larger than imaging shows.  I had two tumors, but the pathologist after surgery measured them together, so I ended up with a larger size.  It has to do with staining the area.  This is a very difficult time, waiting and wondering, so be gentle on yourself.  For me, I read these threads when I was first diagnosed and then stopped until a few weeks after surgery and after I met my oncologist.  I just became to freaked out, I too have panic attacks, so I understand your level of anxiety. I hope all goes well when you meet the surgeon. KEW

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 01:57AM KEW wrote: I chose a bi-lateral because I wanted to reduce the worry, and I wanted the girls to kind of look the same.  I thought one natural and one new would kind of bother me.  It is hard though not having any sensation, sad to never have some of those great feelings again.  I had spent many years thinking about it because of my mother.  I'm glad I did because the pathology report showed DCIS in another part of my left breast, where my tumor was, and if I had a lumpectomy and radiation I probably would have ended up with a mastectomy in a couple of years anyway.  I hesitate to tell that story because it is important that we remember all of our situations are different, I don't want anyone to question their choices.  I'm still at the stage where people can freak me out about my treatment choice.  Because of my Oncotype score and other information about the biology of my tumor I'm not doing chemo, and some people have really frightened me about that choice, even though I feel good about it.  I have decided to have my ovaries out since I'm close to menopause and it feels like a good choice for me, my tumor was an estrogen addict! I miss Marin, but it has changed so much from when I was growing up in the 60's and 70's.  I'm glad I grew up there because of its beauty and being so close to San Francisco and Berkeley. I finally moved out in 1984.  I have a water color painting of the Audobon House at Richardson Bay, by Blackie's Pasture.  Were you there when Blackie was alive.  I fed him carrot as a very little girl.  I just remembered I know another native Marin woman who was diagnosed a couple of years ago, she was probably 43. Thanks for the kind words about my mom, and me.  Same back to you, how's it going for you?
Posts.Title: Marin County BC Ladies out there? jobu Melanie53

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 11:49PM - edited Jan 16, 2009 11:54PM by KEW Hi--I was raised in Marin County, I lived there until I was 24.  As a baby we lived in Tiburon, and later Novato.  My mother died of breast cancer in 1986 at 58 years old, and she had lived in Marin for about 40 years.  If you look at the County Epidemiological page it shows which parts of Marin have elevated incidences of breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 08:35PM - edited Nov 6, 2009 08:37PM by KEW I just got the shot today I work at a medical school, although our unit looks at the environment and human health--not medicine, they had some injectable doses held aside for "compromised" staff and I qualified. I've never had any flu shot, but I'm back in grad school and working 40 hours a week at  my university, so I'm on two campuses--we've had grad students who've gotten H1N1, one of them talked me into getting the vaccine yesterday.  We also just had a student teacher at my son's high school  die from it this week. I've had pneumonia 3 times and had some nodules found in my lungs during a CT a couple of months ago, have to have another CT in a couple of weeks.  I'm not as worried about the H1N1, as I am the number of people getting pneumonia afterwords. Trying to get it for my son seems an impossible task. KarenW
Posts.Title: H1N1 Poll--ALL STAGES WELCOME! badboob67 wildgardener

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2009 10:03PM KEW wrote: I agree with both Binney and Otter.  I used to row and before surgery could military press 100 pounds and was using 20 dumbbells.  I had LE right after surgery and PT worked wonders, and now just have a small patch around the inside of my elbow.  My PS didn't release me for anything over head for 12 weeks, and has me really limited on weight bearing 1-2 pounds, or bands with the PT.  I wear my sleeve whenever I work out, even if it isn't an upper body workout.  I'm trying to get things moving a little bit before my exhcnage/hyster/ooph in May.  I've never gone this long without yoga, etc.  I feel like I have no muscle mass left.  I am doing 1 1/2 cardio workouts on Sat and Sun, 1/2 hour during the week, lower body weights 3 times a week, and a little upper body with resistance twice a week. Binney is right, go slowly, besides you gain more strength with slow movements, those folks you see in the gym screaming, huffing, and puffing, and moving their weights really fast, are not gaining the best benefit for all that work. I would not do anything without seeing a PT first I think  it is very important and can prevent doing the wrong things, and help maximize doing the right ones. Best, Karen

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 10:15PM KEW wrote: Coolbreeze--I used to live in Orangevale.  As far a measuring it varies depending on pathologists. I had two tumors near each other and the pathologist measured them as one, which took me out of Stage I and into Stage II because combined they were over 2cm.  Some pathologists would have measured them individually.  Sometimes staining will show that there is connection so they get measured together.  I've had my BS and 3 oncs explain this to me. hrf--I think after blm and reconstruction an MRI is supposed to be done every couple of years to make sure the implants are in good shape.   KarenW
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 09:33AM KEW wrote: I am so sorry you are going through this.  I'm having a hard time adjusting to the new normal, because I still don't understand what that is, but I surely hope it is better than this.  You sound like a strong and determined woman and you will find yourself in a better place physically and emotionally, it is just taking what seems like an unfairly long time, for sure. I noticed you talked about massaging your arm.  My PT, who is LE licensed, gave me directions on how to do a massage that began at my wrist, down my arm, under my arms, towards the center of my stomach, under my clavicle and up from the groin area towards the stomach--I may have some of it out of order.  This really helped me a lot because it helps to get the whole system moving.  I couldn't get my arm down because I had LE alongside my breast and ribcage, trunk LE maybe? I was backed up.  Once I started doing this regularly, thing began to clear up.  I still have that swelling inside where my elbow bends, but hope it will get better over time.
Posts.Title: Opinions needed on weight lifting and LYmpadema ... naturelover39 LizinKS

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2009 04:10AM KEW wrote: Just one more experience.  I'm a single mom with no family other than my 15 and 20 year old sons, who for obvious reasons, couldn't help much--it isn't there place. I had someone in my life but he ditched when this all came about.  I actually had friends stay for three weeks (about a week each), it was a combination of my needing them and them needing to be here for me.  The first 10 days were the most intense with drains, follow up appts. At first, I couldn't reach high enough up the tube to strip the drains, needed help showering after drains came out, couldn't dry my hair and it I was freezing when it was wet. I was cold for an entire month after the surgery, my heating bill was double from the year before. For me it was good to have another adult in the house to keep my 15 year old on track in school etc.  Folks brought food for about 6 weeks.  I also hired someone to clean the house for me once a week for six weeks (gifts from co-workers paid for this).  I couldn't drive for about 8 weeks because I have a clutch and I couldn't get it into first or reverse.  Have lots of zip up hoodies and slip on shoes, I was unable to dress myself for a couple of weeks, I couldn't get pants on without help, but I had some serious pain on my left side where my drain was. As mentioned above if you have pets, someone to take care of them would be very helpful.  Also, when you have your post op ask your surgeon about cording a fairly common experience, it is when the lymph channels shrink and tighten--it doesn't happen to everyone, but if it feels like you have violin strings under your arms and it hurts to extend your arms  forward you may have some cording.  PT can help with this. I wish you all the best in your surgery and recovery. Karen

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 10:29AM KEW wrote: I really didn't enjoy "I am Not My Breast Cancer."  I thought it was going to an empowering book, but found it to me mostly depressing, with quotes from really unhappy women, who wouldn't be right--I understood that, but it lacked balance and I felt I was going to turn into a breastless, dried up, asexual person, no matter what I did to avoid it. Hated that book.  Karen
Posts.Title: Books Newbies Should Avoid? Sido cookiegal

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 01:52PM KEW wrote: I went to an oncological gyn who wouldn't do a laparoscopic surgery, she went in abdominally because she feels she gets a better look at everything, so my healing 6 weeks--it was difficult to drive my clutch for awhile.  I had everything out, but kept my cervix for bladder and intimacy reasons, so you could ask for some information about that.  I told her ahead of time if she could get my appendix, take that too, and she did.  I do have a scar.  My surgery was in May and a few weeks ago I was having some aching after a workout and her office told me that it takes up to a year for all the internal sutures to absorb.  I was off pain meds in about 8 days (I had my exchange at the same time) but my doc said some women need them for a much longer time, we all have different pain tolerances.  USE A STOOL SOFTENER YOU DON'T WANT TO BE PUSHING HARD,  All in all it wasn't that awful and it hasn't been since.  I think my body was used to low levels of estrogen from being on Tamoxifen for a few months.  I do still have hot flashes, but that really seems to be the only real complaint I have. Good luck! Karen
